周三，波士顿加入旧金山、加利福尼亚州奥克兰和马萨诸塞州剑桥等城市的行列，通过了一项禁止市政使用面部识别技术的投票。它是继旧金山于2019年5月颁布禁令之后，美国第二大禁止面部识别的城市。
该法令获得一致通过，将阻止首都使用面部识别技术或获取使用该技术进行监控的软件。
波士顿市议员米歇尔·吴(Michelle Wu)在周三的听证会上表示，波士顿不应该使用种族歧视技术和威胁我们基本权利的技术。
该法令也有例外，比如允许城市员工使用面部识别进行身份验证，比如解锁自己的设备。市政府官员还可以使用面部识别技术自动编辑图像中的人脸。但他们不能用它来辨认身份。
投票来自市议员里卡多·阿罗约(Ricardo Arroyo)，他与吴一起发起了这项法案。周三的决定使波士顿成为东海岸禁止面部识别的最大城市。
总体而言，它阻止波士顿市政府使用面部识别或从面部识别系统获取信息，或者雇佣可以代表波士顿使用面部识别的第三方。
这项禁令是在全国范围内呼吁警察改革和限制面部识别等监控技术之后出台的。像纽约这样的城市已经通过立法，公开纽约警察局的监控工具，而亚马逊和IBM等公司已经宣布暂停向警察部门出售面部识别。
在研究人员揭露了这项技术的种族和性别偏见后，面部识别受到了广泛的批评。研究突显了这些算法比白人男性更有可能错误识别有色人种和女性，这引发了人们对政府如何使用这项技术的担忧。
市议员利兹·布雷登在听证会上说，监视我们的总体人口并进行面部识别并不一定是我们在自由社会中想要的方式。
美国公民自由联盟(American Civil Liberties Union)周三宣布在底特律提起诉讼，此前警方错误逮捕了被底特律面部识别软件误认的黑人罗伯特·威廉姆斯(Robert Williams)。这是已知的第一起因面部识别不匹配而被捕的案件，但隐私权倡导者担心，如果警方继续使用这项技术，这只是一个开始。
马萨诸塞州美国公民自由联盟(ACLU)执行主任卡罗尔·罗斯(Carol Rose)表示，对于我们的隐私权，以及像罗伯特·威廉姆斯(Robert Williams)这样的人来说，这是一个至关重要的胜利。他们因为执法部门不应该使用的技术而因没有犯下的罪行而被捕。全国的立法者应该效仿，立即停止执法部门使用这项技术。这种监视技术对的时候是危险的，错的时候也是危险的。
波士顿警察局目前没有使用面部识别技术，但周三的投票确保了他们在不久的将来不会使用这项技术。
面部识别本质上是危险的，本质上是压抑的。它不能被改革或监管。数字权利组织“争取未来”(Fight For The Future)的副主任埃文·格里尔(Evan Greer)表示，它必须被废除。波士顿刚刚成为最新一个停止使用这种非同寻常的有毒监控技术的大城市。其他每个城市都应该效仿。
在6月9日波士顿市议会的听证会上，该市警察局长威廉·格罗斯表示，他对面部识别技术不感兴趣，因为这项技术仍然存在种族偏见。

Boston joined cities like San Francisco, Oakland, California, and Cambridge, Massachusetts, on Wednesday in passing a vote to ban facial recognition technology for municipal use. It's the second largest city in the US to ban facial recognition, after  San Francisco enacted its ban in May 2019.
 The ordinance passed unanimously and will prevent the capital city from using facial recognition technology or obtaining software for conducting surveillance using the technology.
  "Boston should not be using racially discriminatory technology and technology that threatens our basic rights," City Councilor Michelle Wu said at the hearing on Wednesday.
 The ordinance comes with exceptions, like allowing city employees to use facial recognition for authentication purposes such as unlocking their own devices. City officials can also use facial recognition technology for automatically redacting faces in images. But they can't use it for identifying people.
 The vote came from City Councilor Ricardo Arroyo, who sponsored the bill with Wu. The decision on Wednesday makes Boston the largest city on the East Coast to ban facial recognition.
 Overall, it prevents the city of Boston from using facial recognition or obtaining information from a facial recognition system, or hiring a third party that can use facial recognition on the city's behalf.
 The ban comes after nationwide calls for police reform and limits on surveillance technology like facial recognition. Cities like New York have passed legislation to  disclose the NYPD's surveillance tools, while companies like  Amazon and  IBM have announced moratoriums on selling facial recognition to police departments.
 Facial recognition has been widely criticized after researchers  exposed the technology's racial and gender bias. Studies highlight how the  algorithms are much more likely to misidentify people of color and women than white men, raising concerns on how governments are using the technology.
  "Surveilling our population at large and doing facial identification is not necessarily the way we want to go in a free society," City Councilor Liz Breadon said at the hearing.
 The  American Civil Liberties Union on Wednesday announced a lawsuit in Detroit after police wrongfully arrested Robert Williams, a Black man misidentified by the city's facial recognition software. It's the first known case of an arrest from a facial recognition mismatch, but privacy advocates worry it's only the beginning if police continue to use the technology.
 "This is a crucial victory for our privacy rights and for people like Robert Williams, who have been arrested for crimes they did not commit because of a technology law enforcement shouldn't be using," said Carol Rose, executive director of the ACLU of Massachusetts."Lawmakers nationwide should follow suit and immediately stop law enforcement use of this technology. This surveillance technology is dangerous when right, and dangerous when wrong."
 Boston's police department doesn't currently use facial recognition, but Wednesday's vote ensures that it can't use the technology in the near future.
 "Facial recognition is inherently dangerous and inherently oppressive. It cannot be reformed or regulated. It must be abolished," said Evan Greer, deputy director of the digital rights group Fight for the Future. "Boston just became the latest major city to stop the use of this extraordinary and toxic surveillance technology. Every other city should follow suit."
 At a  Boston City Council hearing on June 9, the city's Police Commissioner William Gross said he's not interested in facial recognition while the technology is still racially biased.

这一增长可能会受到与投资者的新举措的推动。通过Valence Funding Network，Black创始人和潜在创始人有机会直接接受美国一些顶级风险投资公司的普通合伙人和合伙人的指导和指导。承诺与融资网络合作的26家公司总共管理着超过600亿美元的资产。

瓦伦斯说：“促进创新经济的成功是瓦伦斯使命的关键。通过创建Valence Funding Network，我们正在消除成功的最大结构性障碍之一--接触风险投资者。“。Valence新任首席执行官盖伊·普里姆斯(Guy Primus)说。“我们的使命变得更加清晰。在美国，这是一个紧迫的时刻，我感到有必要帮助实现瓦伦斯使命。2020年表明，对黑人专业人士来说，拥有尽可能多的财务和专业资源是多么重要。

“For years, Black entrepreneurs have been told that Silicon Valley is a meritocracy, but at the same time most haven’t had access to the top networks, the warm introductions, and the mentorship that underpin lasting success in tech. Valence is upending this completely by bringing the top VCs to compete for the best Black entrepreneurs.”  said Valence co-founder, Kobie Fuller, who also works as a general partner at Upfront Ventures. “We want to even the playing field with the goal of exponentially growing the number of Black-owned startups that get funded.”
 Founded in November 2019, Valence is a still-small professional network that provides opportunities for Black entrepreneurs and professionals to connect with peers and mentors. So far, the company has a user base of around eight thousand members, but is growing rapidly, according to Fuller.
   That growth may be boosted by the new initiative with investors. Through the Valence Funding Network Black founders and would-be founders have the opportunity to receive direct pitch coaching and mentorship from general partners and partners at some of the nation’s top venture firms. In all, the 26 firms who have committed to working with the Funding Network represent over $60 billion in assets under management.
   As Valence noted in a press release, Black founders have been historically disenfranchised by the venture capital community. Only   1 percent  of venture-funded startup founders are Black and the company believes that this underrepresentation contributes to America’s racial wealth gap, which sees roughly 13 percent of the United States population, holding less than 3 percent of the nation’s total wealth. It’s Valence’s mission to change this that statistic.
 Along with its new venture capital initiative, the company has also named a new chief executive officer, Guy Primus, the former chief executive of the Virtual Reality Company, an LA-based VR production studio.  Primus also serves on the board of trustees of Southern California Public Radio, where he leads the strategic planning committee and is past chairman of the advisory board at Georgia Tech’s top-ranked school of Industrial and systems engineering.
 “Facilitating success in the innovation economy is key to Valence’s mission. By creating the Valence Funding Network, we are eliminating one of the most formidable structural obstacles to success—the access to venture investors.” said Guy Primus, Valence’s new CEO. “Our mission has come into focus even more clearly. This moment in America is an urgent one and I feel called to help bring the Valence mission to life. 2020 has showcased how important it is for Black professionals to have as many financial and professional resources as possible.

在接受Dling Fireball的约翰·格鲁伯(John Gruber)的采访时，我们得到的确认是，今年晚些时候将推出基于ARM的Apple Silicon的新Mac电脑将无法引导进入ARM Linux发行版。
这些Mac没有Boot Camp版本，引导加载程序可能会被锁定。在它们上运行Linux的唯一方法是从MacOS主机通过虚拟化运行它们。费德里吉说，直接引导的需要不应该是人们关心的问题。
考虑到之前的设计更改，从T(X)控制器的实现开始，级别1这并不让我感到惊讶。如果采用专有CPU架构，则需要编译内核才能在硬件上启动和运行该操作系统。此外，苹果正在转向一项新的存储卷完整性检查验证。可能被锁定在需要苹果硅片的特定机器上。因此，仿真甚至可能无法实现。
第2级，他们有一个虚拟化API。他们显示它运行一些ARM Linux发行版和基于新API的Parallels版本。
第二级，我希望他们不要他妈的花大量的时间给Mac增加价值，因为他们在每一步都在和你竞争。你购买他们的电脑只会助长苹果的行为。
级别2这都是来自LTT的安东尼什么时候能拿到一个的问题。盖伊是个该死的巫师，所以我相信他会找到办法的。
级别1苹果对支持的意思是，他们对此有一个支持流程。他们从来不支持引导Linux，但这是可能的。他们只支持使用BootCamp引导Windows。他们并不支持ARM Mac电脑上的BootCamp，因为为ARM的Windows提供BootCamp并不是任何人关心的事情，对普通买家来说是不必要的困惑，而且Apple Silicon也不存在显卡驱动程序。
这段视频清楚地告诉你，苹果的Silicon Mac仍将启动未经苹果签署的操作系统(尽管他们当然会根据传统MacOS版的使用案例来解释这一点)：https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2020/10686/(18：45)。
级别2是的，还可以看到他们在同一个WWDC谈话中声明csrutil支持禁用安全引导。
2级这仍然不能确认苹果是否仍在使用EFI。如果没有，其他操作系统将很难启动。
第一级有多少人购买Mac来更改其上的操作系统？它是如此少数。无论如何，Linux对Mac硬件的支持一直不稳定。Mac用户群VS那些反对(并且知道什么是)锁定引导加载程序的人拥有非常有限的用户群。
更重要的是，在OSX上编程几乎和在Linux上一样容易。所以程序员的基础不会真的受到那么大的影响。
我总是为供应商宣布不兼容而感到难过。但在我看来，这对我们的社会几乎没有影响。受伤害最大的将是Linux的铁杆用户，他们因工作环境而被迫使用Mac产品。但即便如此；如果您无法控制您的硬件；IT部门可能无论如何都想控制您的东西，所以您无论如何都不应该在上面安装自定义操作系统。
无论如何，组装/购买一台类似规格的Mac要便宜得多。与其他笔记本电脑/个人电脑厂商不同，我认为购买Mac唯一的好处就是设计；不管怎样，自2014年以来，对我来说，这一点一直在走下坡路。
Level 2绝对是少数人，但作为一个非常享受2015年搭载Ubuntu的MacBook Pro体验的人，没有选择是一件令人难过的事情。
级别2真相。我有Mac的唯一原因是要为iOS开发，而我可以用MacOS很好地做到这一点。在上面安装Linux是一件不错的事情，但我不会花时间去做这件事。即使你可以在Linux上为iOS开发，它几乎肯定不会很好地集成，所以在Mac上没有Linux的用例。我的PC上安装了Linux，可以做与iOS无关的工作，不过我也可以在Mac上做web dev的工作。

In an interview with John Gruber of Daring Fireball, we get confirmation that new Macs with ARM-based Apple Silicon coming later this year, will not be able to boot into an ARM Linux distro.
 There is no Boot Camp version for these Macs and the bootloader will presumably be locked down. The only way to run Linux on them is to run them via virtualization from the macOS host. Federighi says "the need to direct boot shouldn't be the concern".
   level 1  This didn’t surprise me, considering the previous design changes, beginning with the implementation of T(x) controllers. With a proprietary CPU architecture, then it would require a compiled kernel for that OS to boot up and run on the hardware. Plus, Apple is moving to a new integrity check validation of storage volumes. Probably locked down to a specific machine that requires the Apple Silicon. So emulation may not even be feasible to accomplish.
 level 2  They have a virtualization api. They shows it running some arm Linux distro with a version of parallels built on the new api.
   level 2  I hope they don't, fuck spending a shit ton of your time adding value to Macs when they're fighting you at every step. You're only encouraging Apple's behavior by buying their computers.
   level 2  It's all a matter of when Anthony from LTT gets his hands on one. Guy's a f-ing wizard so I'm sure he'll find a way.
 level 1  What Apple means with "support" is that they have a support process for this. They never "supported" booting Linux, but it was possible. They only supported booting Windows with Bootcamp. They don't support Bootcamp on ARM Macs really because providing Bootcamp for "Windows for ARM" is not something anyone cares for, needlessly confusing for casual buyers, and no graphics drivers for Apple Silicon exist anyway.
 This video flat out tells you that Apple Silicon Macs will still boot operating systems not signed by Apple (although they of course explain this in terms of the use case of legacy macOS versions):  https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2020/10686/ (18:45).
 level 2  Yeah, also see that they state that csrutil supports disabling secure boot in that same wwdc talk
   level 2  This still doesn’t confirm whether Apple is still using EFI. If not, other OS will have a hard time booting.
       level 1  How many people buy macs to change the OS on them? It's such a minority. Mac hardware support on linux has been always shaky anyway. Mac userbase vs people who are opposed to (and knows what is) locked bootloaders have a very limited userbase.
 Whatmore; it's almost as easy to program on osx as it is on linux. So the programmer base will not really be affected that much.
 I am always sad that vendors announce incompatibilities. But this hardly affects our community as I see it. The ones who are hurt the most would be die-hard linux users that are forced into mac products by their work situations. But even then; if you can't control your hardware; IT department probably wants to control your stuff anyway so you should not be installing a custom OS on there anyway.
 It's much cheaper to assemble/buy a similar spec mac anyways. The only bonus I see on getting a mac as opposed to other laptop/pc vendors is the design; which has been going downhill since 2014 for me anyway.
 level 2  It is definitely a minority, but as someone who greatly enjoyed the experience of a 2015 MacBook Pro with Ubuntu on it, it's sad not to have the option anymore.
  level 2  Truth. The only reason I have a Mac is to develop for iOS and I can do that perfectly well with MacOS. It would be kind of nice to install Linux on it but its not something I'm ever going to spend the time to do. Even if you could develop for iOS on Linux, it almost certainly wouldn't be as well integrated so there's no use case for Linux on the Mac. I have Linux on my PC for doing work that isn't iOS related, though I can do the web dev stuff on the Mac too.

互联网档案馆从20世纪90年代开始，肩负着一个不太可能的使命，成为“亚历山大二号图书馆”；但到2020年，他们可以说已经超过了这一目标，并将他们的藏品直接送到了大众手中。这是美国宇航局对挑战者号航天飞机灾难的重述与1990年康涅狄格州感恩死者现场录音和1979年嘻哈混音磁带逻辑共存的唯一储存库。无论你是需要解决Buffyverse起源的争议，还是要对商标侵权提起诉讼，Wayback机器庞大的旧网页档案都是可接受的证据。你可以用引号搜索电视新闻视频。在撰写本文时，档案馆机器人正在悄悄地手术般地提取腐烂的链接，并将它们替换为Wayback页面(到目前为止已有数百万页)，档案馆正在填写超过10万本书的参考文献，其中包含指向全文页面的实时链接。这些人告诉我们要把我们的狗屎存档，不管怎样，当我们不这样做的时候，他们会为我们保存它。
我们不需要告诉你，但我们正在这么做，因为许多人担心最近由主要出版公司提起的版权诉讼会摧毁互联网档案馆。也许这是炒作-正如Vox指出的那样，诉讼中的最高罚款将略高于1900万美元(2018年互联网档案馆的收入为2000万美元)-起诉书要求永久禁令和销毁作品的“非法复制品”。这将相当于140万本被扫描的图书，但它不会涉及Wayback Machine或公共领域的作品。互联网档案馆的志愿者似乎不同意这种温和的评估；互联网档案馆团队维基目前将互联网档案馆的状态列为“濒危”，并附有一个半开玩笑的参考链接，指向一篇关于这起诉讼的副刊文章。
这可能是几场战斗中的第一场，自开放图书馆项目开始以来，这几场战斗一直在蓄势待发。开放图书馆项目是互联网档案馆的扫描书库，既直接捐赠给档案馆，也从合作图书馆共享。多年来，互联网档案馆一直在为其受控的数字借阅做法辩护，这种做法允许读者在互联网档案馆拥有的每一份硬拷贝中借出一本书，类似于实体图书馆。出版商和作者争辩说，他们绕过了图书馆应该为电子书支付的传统许可费用，因此违反了版权法。图书馆和大学一直支持受控的数字借阅，但在疫情爆发后，互联网档案馆(Internet Archive)暂时降低了这一防御盾牌，取消了所有图书的等待名单，以方便隔离中的在线学习。更多的案件可能迫在眉睫，版权索赔的范围超出了藏书范围，正如维亚康姆最近要求档案馆移除其旧MTV广播集合时所证明的那样。还有参议员汤姆·蒂利斯(共和党-北卡罗来纳州)，出于某种原因，他似乎在互联网档案馆寻找侵犯版权的行为，最近他的目标是从1898年到20世纪50年代从众包的78rpm光盘曲目。
目前有342名潜在借款人在等待罗南·法罗的…的197份数字拷贝。
多读。
这起诉讼提高了一直围绕着互联网档案馆的威胁级别和公众焦虑。如果档案因一千次合法裁剪或太阳耀斑而死亡，硬拷贝可能会腐烂在装运集装箱里；代码将干脆消失。这里有几件这样的珍宝。
马里恩·斯托克斯(Marion Stokes)超越了最近互联网档案馆历史上的显要人物-那些寻找数以千计晦涩难懂的DOS游戏CD-ROM的人，他们花费数年时间从垃圾箱里取出数英里长的胶片。斯托克斯是一位共产主义民权活动家和图书馆管理员，他因录制了30多年的有线电视广播而登上了历史宝座，在任何时候都有多达8台录像机在播放。
去年，一部关于她生活的纪录片“录像机”(Recorder)首次亮相；这部电影描绘了一位受批评镜头驱使的活动家，他的事业变得非常耗费精力，因为有线电视新闻是如何编辑和歪曲现实的。互联网档案馆创始人布鲁斯特·卡勒告诉Gizmodo，他们已经接受了她的“航运集装箱大小”的电视磁带收藏，以便将其数字化。
这项艰巨的努力仍在进行中，但到目前为止，收藏品中大量收录了斯托克斯对“投入”(Input)的录音，这是一档总部位于费城的社会正义脱口秀节目，主持了关于监狱改革的辩论，并以黑豹党(Black Panther Party)的成员为特色，介绍了社会调节。你可以在本期节目中听到斯托克斯驳斥西方关于暴力的观点。
互联网档案馆与约翰·霍普金斯大学图书馆合作，将19世纪废奴主义出版商詹姆斯·伯尼(James Birney)的反奴隶制小册子集数字化并托管。其中包括对奴隶制生活的描述，18世纪英国小册子作家威廉·福克斯(William Fox)提出的著名上诉，以及1849年一名律师在最高法院就取消马萨诸塞州学校种族隔离提出的论点。
历史奴隶制收藏取自联邦作家项目，这是一个工作项目管理项目，以大萧条期间记录的前奴隶的照片和一手记录为特色。有时令人痛苦的冒犯结果反映了刻板印象的抄写，扼杀了出纳员的故事，但这些记述的意义是显而易见的。(它已经在古腾堡计划和国会图书馆的其他地方发布到网上，但互联网档案馆已经将它们以读者友好的图书格式发布，并提供文本搜索。)。
早在90年代，也就是给我们带来互联网档案馆的十年里，斯基普·埃尔斯海默(Skip Elshemer)准备举行剩余的拍卖会，挑选整齐的东西，就像喜鹊档案馆管理员所做的那样。但这是一批16毫米的胶片-500张胶片，售价500美元，大部分是卫生和驾驶教育类的东西-会爆炸成他向世界提供的大量材料，其中很大一部分是通过互联网档案馆。到2020年，他已经从垃圾箱、垃圾填埋场、学校拍卖会和壁橱收集了2.7万部电影。档案馆里有一千多人，其中包括一首关于性病的小歌，一部惊恐而直截了当地再现了青少年偷车事件的电影，以及1957年一部关于原子能的道德辩论电影。(这里是采摘樱桃)。埃尔斯海默还为互联网档案馆将500部公版长篇电影数字化，其中大部分是B级西部片，网上几乎没有或根本没有关于这些电影的信息。“这推出了一百个Roku频道，”埃尔谢默在后来发现人们对他第一次上传的电影收费后开玩笑说。
然而，当被问及一项突出的工作时，埃尔谢默指着他为NASA数字化的一段视频。这是一段航天飞机舱内的视频，就在宇航员的后脑勺，从发射到失重。“这是原始的镜头，不是很有趣。但是因为它不是很有趣，所以对我来说很有趣。你可以看到他们的头在上下摆动，最后当他们进入零重力状态时，他们的头发开始向上抬起……景象和声音……真的很吸引人。“。令人耳目一新的是，它缺乏新闻广播的历史性和NASA Instagram帖子的壮观光泽。
与埃尔斯海默的工作类似，互联网档案馆还收藏了普雷林格档案馆的一大部分，大约有1.7万部数字化电影，大部分是家庭电影和业余作品。(其中包括史无前例的经典影片“鸭子与盖子”(Duck And Cover)，这是一部音乐卡通教育电影，讲述了如何躲在教室桌子下，在核弹中幸存下来。)。还有20世纪40-70年代的教育电影，包括令人愉快的露骨的性内容和对出生奇迹的准确描述。档案馆证实，这些物品中的大多数在其他地方是买不到的。
游戏研究学者、LGBTQ视频游戏档案馆创始人Adrienne Shaw告诉Gizmodo：“互联网档案馆是世界上唯一一个人们可以访问和玩两款最早的LGBTQ视频游戏的地方：卡斯特罗的Caper(1989年)和GayBlade(1992年)。”(卡斯特罗的卡斯特罗是一款谋杀悬疑游戏，主角是一名女同性恋侦探和一名失踪的变装皇后；GayBlade是一款角色扮演游戏，游戏中一群“变装女王、同性恋、女同性恋和其他人”从“令人厌恶的右翼生物”手中营救了一名女皇。)。肖追踪并采访了这两款游戏的设计者-她补充说，她的大部分研究都严重依赖于Wayback Machine，特别是在GayGamer.Net、Gaymer.org和LesbianGamers.com等现已关闭的论坛上的讨论。(肖在花花公子大厦上分享了这篇帖子：“这是我能找到的仅有的几个设计师公开表示打算在游戏中加入同性恋选择的地方之一。”)。
肖告诉Gizmodo：“互联网档案馆在帮助我和创作者30年来第一次将这些游戏放到网上并可以玩的过程中发挥了重要作用。”“这些游戏唯一已知的副本是创建者拥有的，然后被上传到档案馆。如果没有档案，这些LGBTQ游戏历史的关键片段将会丢失。“她说。
同样的情况可能也适用于庞大的游戏存储库。像eXoDOS项目这样的倡议，一群档案管理员通过CD-ROM追踪了数千款DOS游戏，使档案馆能够让数千款丢失的游戏可以供浏览器和笔记本电脑玩。
不要对数量惊人的手册和目录掉以轻心！有古董拖拉机和自动售货机的手册，北卡罗来纳州罗利市20世纪中期黑人所有的企业和教区的目录。这些内容不仅浏览起来有点有趣：它也是一种重要的历史资源，以至于图书馆员杰萨明·韦斯特(Jessamin West)立即将Gizmodo指向“图书馆期刊的关键词可搜索卷！”作为她的网络档案馆宝藏。
首先，他们讲述了州立图书馆协会的故事，他们是历史文化的守门人，韦斯特一直在维基百科上记录和填写他们的历史。他们的历史反映了体制偏见，给予白人员工特权，并排除了他们服务的人群的代表性。韦斯特告诉Gizmodo：“美国南部的许多州协会都是种族隔离的，有些直到1964年的民权法案取消了种族隔离。”“所以，如果你看看，比如说，北卡罗来纳州图书馆协会和北卡罗来纳州黑人图书馆协会(有很好的记录)，你就会真正了解这个‘白化问题’是从哪里来的。”
当Myspace在可疑的情况下“丢失”了5000万首歌曲(“服务器迁移”)，抹去了已故用户的作品和从未制作录音室专辑的粗糙早期歌曲时，互联网档案馆拯救了这一天。在某种程度上。匿名学者提供了近50万首歌曲，用于2008年至2010年的一项研究，在Myspace悲剧报告发布后的几周内，他们就进入了档案馆。我们可能永远无法恢复Myspace的大部分音乐库，但至少有一位Twitter用户又找到了他们的旧东西，这次恢复激励了一群Z世代的档案保管员(他们都是Myspace之前的人)花了几个月的时间整理元数据并重新命名文件。
因此，它是存档的。看看这个由一位前K-Mart员工发起的收藏，他把20世纪70年代到90年代凯马特购物堵塞的录像带上传到了录像带上。购物者们听到了Kmart的辉煌历史，混杂着普通的流行音乐和软摇滚。投稿人还添加了世纪中叶来自S.S.Kresge公司的员工培训片段，该公司是一家百货商店连锁店，位于凯马特(Kmart)名称之前。为什么我要包括这个？因为这就是作案手法：何乐而不为。
更正6/5，8：12，美国东部时间：这篇帖子已经更新，以澄清互联网档案馆的“濒危”状态不是一个被批准的标签，而是来自志愿者运营的档案馆团队维基。Gizmodo对造成的混乱表示遗憾。
在互联网上，我们每天都依赖某些机构来向…隐瞒真相。

The Internet Archive set out in the 1990s with an   improbable mission to become the “Library of Alexandria Two”;  by 2020, they’ve arguably surpassed that goal, plus delivered their collection straight to the masses. It’s the only repository where   a NASA recap of the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster logically coexists with a 1990 recording of the Grateful Dead   live in Connecticut and   a 1979 hip hop mix tape. Whether you need to settle a dispute over the origins of the Buffyverse, or you’re litigating trademark infringement, the Wayback machine’s vast archive of old webpages  is   admissible evidence. You can search for TV news videos    by quotes. At this writing, the   archive bot is quietly, surgically extracting rotten links and replacing them with Wayback pages (millions so far), and the archive is filling in over 100,000 book references with live links to pages in full texts. These are the guys who tell us to   archive our shit and save it for us anyway when we don’t.
    We don’t need to tell you, but we’re doing it, because many are worried that a recent copyright lawsuit brought by major publishing companies will decimate the Internet Archive. Maybe that’s   hype—as Vox has pointed out, the maximum penalties under the lawsuit would amount to a little over $19 million dollars (the Internet Archive’s revenue in 2018 was $20 million)—and the   complaint asks for a permanent injunction and destruction of “unlawful copies” of works. That would amount to 1.4 million   scanned books, but it wouldn’t touch the Wayback Machine or public domain works. The Internet Archive’s volunteers seem to disagree with the tempered assessment; the   Archive Team wiki currently lists the Internet Archive’s status as “endangered,” with a tongue-in-cheek reference link to a   Vice article on the lawsuit.
 This could be the first of several battles, which have been gearing up since the inception of the Open Library project, the Internet Archive’s  depot of scanned books, both donated directly to the archive and shared from partner libraries. For years, the Internet Archive has been defending its controlled digital lending practice that allows readers to check out one book per each hard copy the Internet Archive owns, similar to a physical library. Publishers and authors   argue that they’re skirting around the traditional licensing payments libraries are expected to make for e-books and therefore violating copyright law. Libraries and universities have   stood by controlled digital lending, but after the outbreak of the pandemic, the Internet Archive temporarily lowered that defensive shield  by   eliminating its waitlist for all books in order to facilitate online learning in quarantine. More cases could loom, and copyright claims reach beyond the book collection, as Viacom recently proved when it demanded the archive remove its   collection of old MTV broadcasts. And then there’s Senator Thom Tillis (R.-NC) who for some reason   seems to be hunting for copyright violations in the Internet Archive,   lately aiming at its   crowd-sourced repertoire of 78 rpm discs from 1898 to the 1950s.

 The suit raises the threat level and the public anxiety that’s always surrounded the Internet Archive. If the archive were to die by a thousand legal cuts or a solar flare, hardcopies could rot in shipping containers; code would simply vanish. Here are a few of those treasures.
      Marion Stokes towers over the recent dignitaries of Internet Archive history—those who hunt down thousands of obscure CD-ROMs of DOS games, they who spend years pulling miles of film from dumpsters. Stokes, a communist civil rights activist and librarian, has assumed a historical throne for recording over three decades of cable TV broadcasts, with up to eight VCRs running at all times.
 A   documentary about her life,  Recorder, debuted last year; the film portrays an activist driven by a critical lens on how cable news edits and distorts reality, whose undertaking became all-consuming. Internet Archive founder Brewster Kahle told Gizmodo that they’ve taken on her “shipping container sized” TV tape collection in order to digitize it.
  That Herculean effort is still underway, but so far, the collection heavily features Stokes’s recordings of “Input,” a 1960s-1970s Philadelphia-based social justice talk show which hosted debates on   prison reform and featured members of the   Black Panther Party on social conditioning. You can hear Stokes refute Western ideas about violence   in this episode.
    The Internet Archive worked with Johns Hopkins University’s library to digitize and host 19th century abolitionist publisher James Birney’s collection of anti-slavery pamphlets. It includes   descriptions of life in slavery,   a famous appeal by 18th century British pamphleteer William Fox, and a lawyer’s   1849 argument before the Supreme Court for desegregating Massachusetts schools.
 The Historical Slavery Collection pulled from the Federal Writers’ Project, a Work Projects Administration program, features photos and volumes of first-hand   accounts from former slaves, recorded during the Depression. The sometimes painfully offensive outcome reflects stereotyping transcriptions that butcher the teller’s story, but the significance of the accounts is clear. (This has been posted online elsewhere on Project Gutenberg and the Library of Congress, but the Internet Archive has posted them in a reader-friendly book format with text search.)
     Back in the 90s, the decade that brought us the Internet Archive, Skip Elsheimer was going to state surplus auctions, picking out neat stuff, as magpie archivists do. But it was a batch of 16 millimeter films—500 films for 500 bucks, mostly hygiene and driver’s ed type stuff—that would explode into a trove of material that he’s made available to the world, in large part via the Internet Archive. By 2020, he’s amassed a collection of 27,000 films from dumpsters, landfills, school auctions, and closets. Over a thousand are   on the archive, including a little song about   venereal diseases, a scared-straight   reenactment of teen grand theft auto, and a 1957 film   moral debate over atomic energy. (Cherry-picking here). Elsheimer has also digitized 500 public domain feature-length films for the Internet Archive, mostly B Westerns, about which little or no information was available online. “That launched a hundred Roku channels,” Elsheimer joked, after later finding people charging for films he’d first uploaded.
 When asked for a work that sticks out, though, Elsheimer pointed to a video he digitized for NASA. It’s a video from inside the cabin of a shuttle, just the back of astronauts’ heads, from launch to zero gravity. “It’s raw footage, it’s not very interesting. But  because it’s not very interesting, to me it’s very interesting. You see their heads bobbing, and eventually as they get into zero gravity, their hair starts to lift up...the sights and the sounds...it’s really fascinating.” It refreshingly lacks the historicizing of news broadcasts and the spectacular sheen of NASA Instagram posts.
  Similar to Elsheimer’s work, the Internet Archive also hosts a large chunk of the Prelinger Archives, a collection of around 17,000 digitized films, mostly of home movies and amateur works. (It includes the all-time classic “  Duck and Cover,” the musical cartoon educational film on how to survive a nuclear bomb by ducking under a classroom desk.) There are also the 1940s-1970s   educational films including delightfully explicit   sexual content and an accurate depiction of   the miracle of birth. Most of these items, the Archive confirmed, are not available anywhere else.
    “The Internet Archive is the only place in the world people can access and play the two earliest know LGBTQ video games:   Caper in the Castro (1989) and   GayBlade (1992),” gaming studies scholar and founder of the LGBTQ Video Game Archive Adrienne Shaw told Gizmodo. (Caper in the Castro is a murder mystery game featuring a lesbian detective and a missing drag queen; GayBlade is a role-playing game where a team of “drag queens, queers, lesbians, and others” rescue an empress from “disgusting right-wing creatures.”) Shaw tracked down and interviewed the   designers of   both—and she added that she’s relied heavily on the Wayback Machine for much of her research, especially discussions on now-shuttered forums like GayGamer.Net, Gaymer.org, and LesbianGamers.com. (Shaw shared   this post on the Playboy Mansion: “It’s one of the only places I can find a designer speaking openly on the intention to include gay options in the game.”)
 “The Internet Archive played an instrumental role in helping me and the creators get those games online and playable for the first time in 30 years,” Shaw told Gizmodo. “These are games that the only known copies are those that the creators had, that were then uploaded to the archive. These crucial pieces of LGBTQ game history would be lost,” she said, if not for the archive.
  The same would likely go for a vast repository of games. Initiatives like the   eXoDOS project, a group of archivists who tracked down thousands of DOS games on CD-ROMs, has allowed the archive   to make thousands of lost titles available for browser and laptop play.
    Don’t discount the staggering magnitude of manuals and directories! There are manuals for antique   tractors and   vending machines, directories   for mid-20th century Black-owned businesses and   parishes in Raleigh, N.C. This content isn’t just kinda interesting to skim: it’s also a critical historical resource, so much so that librarian Jessamyn West immediately pointed Gizmodo to “keyword searchable volumes of Library Journal!” as her Internet Archive treasure.
  For one, they tell the story of state library associations, historical cultural gatekeepers, whose history West has been documenting and filling out on Wikipedia. Their histories reflect institutional biases, privileging white staff and excluding representation of the populations they serve. “Many state associations in the Southern U.S. were segregated, some until the Civil Rights Act of 1964 MADE them desegregate,” West told Gizmodo. “So if you look at, say, the   North Carolina Library Association and the   North Carolina Negro Library Association (which is well-documented) you really get a sense of just where this ‘whiteness problem’ came from.”
     When Myspace   “lost” 50 million songs under dubious circumstances (a “server migration”), wiping out work by deceased users and rough early songs that never made studio albums, it was the Internet Archive that saved the day. To a degree. Anonymous academics offered the archive nearly half a million songs, used for a 2008 to 2010 study, and within weeks of the Myspace tragedy reports,   they were up on the archive. We may never recover the majority of Myspace’s music library, but at least one Twitter   user found their old stuff again, and the recovery inspired a group of Gen Z archivists (all who’d preceded Myspace) to   spend months sorting through metadata and renaming the files.
    It is, therefore, it’s archived. See this collection started by a former K-Mart employee, who uploaded tapes upon tapes of 1970s to 1990s   Kmart shopping jams. Shoppers got an earful of the   glorious history of Kmart, mixed with generic pop and soft rock. Contributors have also added midcentury   employee training clips from the S. S. Kresge Company, department store chain that preceded the Kmart name. Why am I including this? Because that’s the M.O.: why not.

The Linux 5.9 kernel is slated to begin introducing new restrictions on allowing writes to CPU model specific registers (MSRs) from user-space.   Via the Linux kernel x86 MSR driver, writes to arbitrary model specific registers from user-space is allowed -- assuming you have root permissions. But even with requiring root access, there are security implications and other issues in allowing any CPU MSRs to be written to from user-space without the intervention of the kernel via  /dev/cpu/[CPU-number]/msr.   SUSE's Borislav Petkov has added support to the x86 MSR driver to begin filtering of MSR writes. Petkov reinforced, " Having unfettered access to all MSRs on a system is and has always been a disaster waiting to happen. Think performance counter MSRs, MSRs with sticky or locked bits, MSRs making major system changes like loading microcode, MTRRs, PAT configuration, TSC counter, security mitigations MSRs, you name it. This also destroys all the kernel's caching of MSR values for performance, as the recent case with MSR_AMD64_LS_CFG showed. Another example is writing MSRs by mistake by simply typing the wrong MSR address. System freezes have been experienced that way. In general, poking at MSRs under the kernel's feet is a bad bad idea."   The new default behavior starting with Linux 5.9 will be to log messages to  dmesg whenever a MSR write from user-space happens with a "write to unrecognized MSR" notification.   But this MSR filtering infrastructure also adds the ability to block MSR writes from user-space. Ultimately they will likely transition to that as the default at a later time to ensure MSR writes from user-space do not happen. This behavior right now can be toggled via the  msr.allow_writes= kernel module paramrter with on/off/default. Should legitimate use-cases come up where writes to MSRs from user-space are still desired, they may add the infrastructure to selectively grant/deny access to specific MSRs and ensure they are sanitized by the kernel.

Mozilla在今天的声明中说，康卡斯特是第一家加入火狐可信递归解析器(TRR)计划的ISP。CloudFlare和NextDNS已经在Mozilla的计划中，该计划要求加密DNS提供商必须满足隐私和透明度标准，并承诺默认情况下不会阻止或过滤域，除非解析程序所在司法管辖区的法律特别要求。
公告称，在TRR计划中加入ISP为客户提供可信DNS解析的安全性铺平了道路，同时还提供了ISP提供的解析器的好处，如家长控制服务和更优化、本地化的结果。Mozilla和Comcast将联合运行测试，以告知Firefox如何将最佳可用的TRR分配给每个用户。
火狐首席技术官埃里克·雷斯考拉表示，将ISP纳入TRR计划有助于我们在不破坏现有用户体验的情况下保护在线用户隐私，Mozilla希望今天的新闻能为浏览器和ISP之间的进一步合作开创先例。
加入Mozilla的计划意味着康卡斯特同意保留、出售或转让来自Firefox浏览器发送的DNS查询中的任何个人信息、IP地址或其他用户标识符或用户查询模式给任何第三方(法律可能要求的除外)，以及其他要求。Mozilla在今天的声明中指出，加密DNS是迈向隐私的第一步，但不是唯一必要的步骤。
Firefox在2月份开始向美国用户提供默认的基于HTTPS的DNS(DoH)和Cloudflare。
Mozilla和康卡斯特港湾没有透露康卡斯特加密的DNS何时可以在Firefox上使用。无论何时发生，除非用户选择了不同的DoH提供商或完全禁用了DoH，否则更改应该是自动的。康卡斯特昨天告诉ARS，Xfinity上的Firefox用户应该自动默认使用Mozilla的Trusted Recursive Resolver程序下的Xfinity解析器，除非他们手动选择了不同的解析器，或者DoH被禁用。这种精确的机制仍在测试中，两家公司计划很快将其记录在IETF[互联网工程任务组]草案中。

霍宾正忙着伸缩。该公司首席执行官约翰尼·鲍法哈特(Johnny Boufarhat)表示，该公司今年的员工基础已从8人增加到60人，目标是到2020年底有200人。随着其技术的使用范围扩大，该公司正在增加人员，据该公司称，使用其技术举办的“活动的月度参与者数量”从3月份的16,000人-当时新冠肺炎的封锁正在加速-增加到5月份的175,000人。
这就是风险资本家手持支票簿蜂拥而至的那种增长。更好的是，Hopin目前的营销成本约为零，因为想要在该公司的平台上举办活动的团体超过了它所能处理的范围。
为什么虚拟活动技术提供商会有瓶颈？“Hopin是一个场所，”Boufarhat在接受TechCrunch采访时表示，这意味着它的客户需要支持，以确保他们使用该软件时一切顺利。鲍法哈特解释说，如果一项商业技术出现几分钟的问题，并以CRM为例，这并不是世界末日。他解释说，如果Hopin实例有问题，1000人可能会受到影响，导致他们同时判断托管小组和他的公司。
霍宾的技术可以让活动重现传统的面对面在线会议。这包括允许东道主拥有真实活动地点和活动的数字等价物的功能，如世博会中心、不同的舞台和网络功能。这种IRL在线聚会的镜像，可以使数字活动对已经习惯于某种聚集方式的参与者更具吸引力。
Hopin在2019年10月首次筹集资金，当时正处于快速扩张时期。据布法哈特称，他的初创公司环比增长约60%。当时，该公司的经营是减少进入，只接受一部分市场需求。在10月份的一轮融资完成后，该业务不断增长，使其能够收集更多有关其产品及其使用方式的数据。
这一信息导致了2020年2月的种子轮。据该公司首席执行官称，当时该公司的收入与支出大致成正比，这使得它在这段时间里“几乎实现了盈利”。对于风险资本家来说，看到一家需求超过其承受能力的公司实现增长，同时又不会损失太多-如果有的话-是有吸引力的。
霍宾在2020年初的快速融资并不令人意外。同样的因素汇聚在一起，包括使用增长和收入增长，也是其最近的首轮系列赛的原因。
新冠肺炎似乎是霍平的助燃剂。随着疫情的蔓延，该公司意识到公司将从面对面的活动转向网络研讨会，在它看来，这并不是很好。因此，它比原计划更早地采取行动，让霍平更容易获得。
现在，有了比迄今为止更多的资金，Hopin很可能可以加快招聘速度，并接纳比以前更多的客户。这意味着更多的虚拟活动，以及公司更多的收入。看看该公司的毛利率随着时间的推移是如何形成的，以及它帮助举办的活动的复发率是多少，这将是一件有趣的事情。如果利润率良好，而且事件是周期性的，该公司可能会主张长期使用SaaS倍数。
展望未来，看看该公司如何接近数字世界领域，以及目前的模式是否有空间提供更多VR风格的体验，这将是一件有趣的事情。而在远处还有其他问题，包括当最终为新冠肺炎找到疫苗时会发生什么？事件是恢复正常，还是最终分裂了IRL-Online的鸿沟，让Hopin和类似的公司在会议中永远占有一席之地？
像Teeoh甚至Eventbrite这样的公司也想在虚拟活动市场分一杯羹，这样Hopin就不会走人了。也就是说，几乎没有迹象表明虚拟活动主办将是一个单一的赢家类别。考虑到事件世界的纯粹TAM，可能有容纳几个人的空间。
霍平再次加薪的速度有多快，应该会给我们下一个关于其增长速度的信号。我们有的时候会更多。
note_en:
The round comes after Hopin had raised relatively modest capital before, including  a $6.5 million round in February of this year.
 Hopin is busy scaling. The company has seen its employee base grow from eight to sixty this year, and targets 200 by the end of 2020, according to CEO  Johnny Boufarhat. The firm is staffing up as usage of its technology expands, with the “number of monthly attendees of events” hosted using its technology growing from 16,000 in March — when COVID-19 lockdowns were accelerating — to 175,000 in May, according to the company.
  That’s the sort of growth that venture capitalists flock to, checkbooks in hand. Even better, Hopin’s current marketing costs are around zero, as there’s simply more groups that want to host events on the company’s platform than it can handle.
 Why does a virtual event technology provider have a bottleneck? “Hopin is a venue,” Boufarhat told TechCrunch in an interview, meaning that its customers need support to make sure things go well when they use the software. If a piece of business technology hiccups for a few minutes, Boufarhat explained, citing CRM as an example, it’s not the end of the world. If a Hopin instance has issues, he explained, 1,000 people could be impacted, causing them to judge both the hosting group and his company.
 Hopin’s technology allows events to recreate the traditional in-person conference, online. This includes features that allow hosts to have digital equivalents of real-world event locations and activities, like expo centers, various stages, and networking capabilities. This mirroring of an IRL get-together, online, could make digital events more attractive to attendees who have become accustomed to a certain method of congregating.
  Hopin first raised money in October of 2019, during a period of rapid expansion. According to Boufarhat, his startup was seeing about 60% growth, month-to-month. At that time the company was operating with reduced entry, only accepting a portion of market demand. After the October round was complete, the business kept growing, allowing it to collect more data on its product and how it was used.
 That information led to its February, 2020 Seed round. Back then the company was seeing revenue scale roughly along with expenses, allowing it to be “nearly profitable” during the period, according to its CEO. For venture capitalists, seeing a company with more demand than it can handle grow, while also not losing much — if any — money is attractive.
 Hopin’s quick round in early 2020 then was not a surprise. The same confluence of factors, including usage growth and revenue expansion, are also what came together for its most-recent Series A.
 COVID-19 was an accelerant for Hopin, it appears. As the pandemic spread, the company realized that companies were going to switch from in-person events to webinars, which, in its view, aren’t great. So, it moved to make Hopin more available, earlier, than planned.
 Now with more money than it has had to-date, Hopin can likely accelerate its hiring, and onboard more clients than before. That means more virtual events, and more revenue for the company. It will be interesting to see how the company’s gross margins shape up over time, and what percent of the events that it helps host recur. If the margins are good, and events periodic, the firm could argue for a SaaS multiple long-term.
  Looking towards the future, it will be interesting to see how the company approaches the realm of digital worlds, and if there’s space in its current model for more VR-style experiences. And there are other questions in the distance, including what happens when a vaccine is eventually found for COVID-19? Do events go back to normal, or do they wind up splitting the IRL-online divide, giving Hopin and similar companies a place in conferences for good?
 Firms like  Teeoh and  even Eventbrite also want a piece the virtual event market, so Hopin won’t have a walkover. That said, there’s little indication yet that virtual event hosting will be a single-winner category. Given the sheer TAM of the events world, there’s probably room for several.
 How quickly Hopin raises again should give us our next signal regarding the pace of its growth. More when we have it.

Storyblock首席执行官TJ Leonard在今天宣布之前告诉我：“我们的使命实际上就是关于负担得起和获得的想法。”“这是我们DNA的核心。它永远都会是。但是，当我们展望未来时，我们会在客户的整个工作流程中为他们提供支持，因为他们正在努力跟上受众的内容需求。你把所有这些放在一起，感觉现在是采取下一步的正确时机。最新消息，北大西洋资本(North Atlantic Capital)、QED[投资者]-我们所有的早期投资者-在过去八年里为支持我们的业务做出了令人惊叹的工作，帮助我们走到了这一步。但Great Hill带来了过往的记录--我认为这是一种专业知识--这对我们来说是下一阶段的完美选择。“。
伦纳德和团队的其他成员一样留了下来，他指出，Storyblock是盈利的，并没有积极试图筹集任何资金来维持业务或寻求退出。相反，他认为，这笔交易只是一个合乎逻辑的过程。
“我们很早就觉得，即使企业有十几年的历史，我们的故事还是有很多篇章的。我们真的很兴奋能继续追捕他们，“他说。“我们一直在说，如果我们要找到一个新的合作伙伴，我们的第一个标准是，他们需要相信我们拥有的同样的使命和愿景，他们需要相信我们看到的同样的市场机会-他们需要感觉到我们拥有正确的模式和正确的团队来利用这个机会。”随着我们对Great Hill有了更多的了解，很明显，我们在所有这些重要的问题上都非常一致。“。
他还指出，他倾向于认为Great Hill是“一家以增长为导向的私募股权投资者，几乎是伪装成私募股权结构的成长型股权投资者”，因为该公司倾向于收购公司，但随后也经常将其再次剥离。“我们所有的对话都是围绕着我们如何改变今天正在进行的事情并加速进行的。我们如何看待我们的长期战略增长计划，即在未来五年内设定一定的目标，并在三年内实现这些目标，“他说。
伦纳德告诉我，Storyblock将继续像往常一样运营，并继续投资于其内容库。新冠肺炎只是提高了对库存镜头的需求(Storyblock现在每周的下载量是2020年初的两倍)，但在疫情爆发之前，该公司已经看到对其服务的需求不断增长，很大程度上是因为对视频内容的需求只会继续增加。
“这感觉不像是个结局。感觉我们有很多好的工作要做，“伦纳德说。“感觉在很多方面，市场正在追赶我们自成立以来的信念，那就是，如果你能帮助人们创造更多高质量的视频内容，以负担得起的价格，以节省他们时间的方式做到这一点，那么那里就有一个巨大的机会。”
note_en:
Storyblocks was founded in 2009 and raised about $18.5 million since its launch. Over the years, it went through a few changes. Its early focus was on video content and until 2017, it operated under the VideoBlocks moniker (before that, it was FootageFirm). The company’s focus was always on its buffet-style subscription service, though it also offered an “a la carte” marketplace for one-time purchases. Only a small fraction of users actually bought from the marketplace, so last year, it  doubled down on its subscription library.
 “Our mission was really all about this idea of affordability and access,” Storyblocks CEO TJ Leonard told me ahead of today’s announcement. “That’s core to our DNA. It always will be. But as we look to the future, we see ourselves supporting our customers across their entire workflow as they work to keep up with the content demand of their audience. You wrap all that together and it felt like the moment was right to take the next step. Update, North Atlantic Capital, QED [Investors] — all of our early investors — have done an awesome job supporting the business over the last eight years to help us get to this point. But Great Hill brings a track record — and I think an expertise — that is perfect for this next stage for us.”
   Leonard, who just like the rest of the team is staying on, noted that Storyblocks is profitable and wasn’t actively trying to raise any capital to sustain its business or looking for an exit. Instead, he argued, this sale was simply a logical progression.
 “We’ve long felt that even though the business is more than ten years old, there’s still a lot of chapters left in our story. We’re really excited to continue to chase them down,” he said. “And we’ve said all along that if we were going to find a new partner, our first criteria was that they needed to believe in the same mission and vision that we had, they needed to believe the same market opportunity that we saw — and they needed to feel like we had the right model and the right team to go take advantage of that opportunity. As we got to know Great Hill better, it was clear that we were really well aligned across all those important points.”
 He also noted that he tends to think of Great Hill as “a growth-oriented private equity investor, almost a growth equity investor masquerading with a private equity structure” given that the firm tends to acquire companies but then also often spins them out again. “All of our conversations have been oriented around how do we change what’s working today and accelerate it. How do we take our long term strategic growth plan that sets certain goals over the next five years and accomplish them in three,” he said.
 Storyblocks will continue to operate as usual and continue to invest in its content libraries, Leonard told me. COVID-19 only made the demand for stock footage go up (Storyblocks now sees twice as many downloads per week compared to the start of 2020), but the company was already seeing a growing demand for its service before the pandemic, in large parts because the demand for video content only continues to increase.
 “This doesn’t feel like an ending. It feels like we have a lot of good work to do,” said Leonard. “It feels like in a lot of ways, the market is just kind of catching up to what we’ve believed since our founding, which is that if you can help people create more high-quality video content, do it at an affordable price, do it in a way that saves them time, then there’s a huge opportunity out there.”

这项挑战向“全球创新者社区”中的任何人开放，为期八周，优胜者最高可获得3.5万美元的奖金。令人惊讶的是，这并不是NASA第一次利用人群的力量，以及HeroX的众包平台，提出围绕人类排泄物管理的创新技术：2016年的Space Poop挑战赛吸引了很多关注，并向三名获奖者颁发了总计3万美元的奖金。
那次比赛的重点是设计一种专门供完全穿着宇航服的宇航员使用的系统，这与为这次挑战寻求的厕所设计有很大的不同，当宇航员穿上又大又笨重的EVA套装时，他们可以在阿耳特弥斯着陆器内的月球之旅中使用，宇航员将使用这些宇航员返回月球表面。NASA指出，虽然美国宇航局已经在国际空间站上安装了工作良好的微重力厕所，但月球的低重力条件将需要不同的设计，而且月球之旅的性质意味着他们将寻找更小、更省电的设计-因为当你发射一艘自给自足的宇宙飞船时，每一盎司和每一瓦的功率都很重要。
当然，美国国家航空航天局并不是完全依靠观众来设计独特和创新的太空厕所。它已经在致力于将现有的内部版本微型化。但该机构希望向外部学者、研究人员、设计师和工程师开放这一领域，因为他们希望来自航空航天行业以外的新视角可以帮助他们看到潜在的解决方案，否则习惯于在该领域工作的人不会想到这些解决方案。
note_en:
The challenge is open to anyone in the “global community of innovators,” and will span eight weeks, with up to $35,000 in prizes available to the competitors winners. Surprisingly, this isn’t actually the first time that NASA has enlisted the power of the crowd, and HeroX’s crowdsourcing platform, to come up with innovative technology around human waste management: its  Space Poop challenge from 2016 garnered a lot of attention and awarded a total of $30,000 to three winners.
 That competition focused on designing a system specifically for use by fully space-suited astronauts, which is quite different from the toilet designs sought for this challenge, which will be able to be used by astronauts when they’re out of their big, bulky EVA suits during the trip to the Moon within the Artemis landers that astronauts will be using to return to the lunar surface. NASA notes that while the agency already has microgravity toilets that work perfectly well in use on the International Space Station, the low gravity conditions of the Moon will require different designs, and also the nature of the trip to the Moon mean that they’ll be looking for smaller, more power efficient designs – since when you’re launching a self-contained spaceship, every ounce and every watt of power used matters a great deal.
  NASA isn’t fully relying on the crowd to come up with unique and innovative space toilet designs, of course. It’s already working on miniaturization of existing versions in-house. But the agency wants to open this up to outside academics, researchers, designers and engineers because they’re hoping that fresh perspective from outside the aerospace industry can help them see potential solutions that otherwise wouldn’t have occurred to people used to working in the field.

note_en:
The  COVID-19 Earth Observation Data provides views into changes globally in water quality, climate change, economic activity and also agriculture. It’s intended to provide policymakers, health authorities, city planners and others with key information that they can use to study both short- and long-term impacts of the ongoing global COVID-19 crisis, which is definitely changing the way that cities and the people within them work and live.
 The agencies involved in the project formed a project for the purposes of building this in April, so it came together rather quickly for a cross-agency, international collaboration. Data so far indicates significant changes, including positive environmental ones around air and water quality due to decreased activity – but also significant slowdowns in key economic activity including shipping activity in ports, the number of cars in shopping mall parking lots, and more.
  While the project is specifically intended to provide data around COVID-19 and its impacts, and the current plan only includes the pandemic within its scope, on a call discussing the initiative,  ESA   Director of Earth Observation Programmes Josef Aschbacher said that the agencies are already considering whether to extend he dashboard beyond the scope of COVID-19 since it could be useful in addressing any number of global-scale problems that we collectively face.

Alexa von Tobel   takes that breadth of experience and those unique insights to a new level, as a founder who has pretty much exclusively started her ventures in the midst of a recession. So it should come as no surprise that we’re absolutely amped to be sitting down (virtually, of course) with von Tobel for an episode of  Extra Crunch Live today at 11am PT/2pm ET. (Full details after the jump.)
 LearnVest was founded by von Tobel in 2006, just before the crash of ’08, and was poised to grow voraciously due to the economic landscape of the time. The personal finance platform raised a total of $72 million over the following years and was ultimately  acquired by Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance in 2015.
 In 2019, von Tobel  launched Inspired Capital, a $200 million early-stage firm that has invested in Chief, Finix, SnackPass and Rho Business Banking.
 And here we are, in the midst of yet another recession with  some 30 million people out of a job due primarily to the coronavirus pandemic.
 Von Tobel says that, in times of economic uncertainty like these, startups have a real opportunity to disrupt and accelerate.
 We’ll chat with von Tobel about how she’s advising her portfolio companies right now, the biggest lessons she’s learned throughout her career, her thoughts on how tech can improve diversity and inclusion efforts in the wake of the murder of George Floyd, and which trends and sectors she’s most interested in pursuing right now.
